cloneSubgraph.name: apoc.refactor.cloneSubgraph([node1,node2,...], [rel1,rel2,...]:[], {standinNodes:[], skipProperties:[]}) YIELD input, output, error | clone nodes with their labels and properties (optionally skipping any properties in the skipProperties list via the config map), and clone the given relationships (will exist between cloned nodes only). If no relationships are provided, all relationships between the given nodes will be cloned. Relationships can be optionally redirected according to standinNodes node pairings (this is a list of list-pairs of nodes), so given a node in the original subgraph (first of the pair), an existing node (second of the pair) can act as a standin for it within the cloned subgraph. Cloned relationships will be redirected to the standin.
cloneSubgraph.description: apoc.refactor.cloneSubgraph(nodes :: LIST? OF NODE?, rels = [] :: LIST? OF RELATIONSHIP?, config = {} :: MAP?) :: (input :: INTEGER?, output :: NODE?, error :: STRING?)

Relationships can be optionally redirected according to standinNodes node pairings (this is a list of list-pairs of nodes), so given a node in the original subgraph (first of the pair), an existing node (second of the pair) can act as a standin for it within the cloned subgraph. relationship.name: apoc.nodes.relationship.types(node|nodes|id|[ids], rel-direction-pattern) - returns a list of maps where each one has two fields: `node` which is the node subject of the analysis and `types` which is a list of distinct relationship types
relationship.description: apoc.nodes.relationship.types(ids :: ANY?, types =  :: STRING?) :: (LIST? OF ANY?)

connected.name: apoc.nodes.connected(start, end, rel-direction-pattern) - returns true when the node is connected to the other node, optimized for dense nodes
connected.description: apoc.nodes.connected(start :: NODE?, start :: NODE?, types =  :: STRING?) :: (BOOLEAN?)

delete.name: apoc.nodes.delete(node|nodes|id|[ids]) - quickly delete all nodes with these ids

group.name:
apoc.nodes.group(labels :: LIST? OF STRING?, groupByProperties :: LIST? OF STRING?, aggregations = [{*=count}, {*=count}] :: LIST? OF MAP?, config = {} :: MAP?) :: (nodes :: LIST? OF NODE?, relationships :: LIST? OF RELATIONSHIP?, node :: NODE?, relationship :: RELATIONSHIP?)
----

relationships.name: apoc.nodes.relationships.exist(node|nodes|id|[ids], rel-direction-pattern) - returns a list of maps where each one has two fields: `node` which is the node subject of the analysis and `exists` which is a map with rel-pattern, boolean for the given relationship patterns
relationships.description: apoc.nodes.relationships.exist(ids :: ANY?, types =  :: STRING?) :: (LIST? OF ANY?)

undefined.name: Provides descriptions of available procedures. To narrow the results, supply a search string. To also search in the description text, append + to the end of the search string.
undefined.description: apoc.help(proc :: STRING?) :: (type :: STRING?, name :: STRING?, text :: STRING?, signature :: STRING?, roles :: LIST? OF STRING?, writes :: BOOLEAN?, core :: BOOLEAN?)

undefined.name: apoc.when(condition, ifQuery, elseQuery:'', params:{}) yield value - based on the conditional, executes read-only ifQuery or elseQuery with the given parameters
undefined.description: apoc.when(condition :: BOOLEAN?, ifQuery :: STRING?, elseQuery =  :: STRING?, params = {} :: MAP?) :: (value :: MAP?)

undefined.name: apoc.case([condition, query, condition, query, ...], elseQuery:'', params:{}) yield value - given a list of conditional / read-only query pairs, executes the query associated with the first conditional evaluating to true (or the else query if none are true) with the given parameters
undefined.description: apoc.case(conditionals :: LIST? OF ANY?, elseQuery =  :: STRING?, params = {} :: MAP?) :: (value :: MAP?)

undefined.name: RETURN apoc.version() | return the current APOC installed version

fromData.name: apoc.graph.fromData([nodes],[relationships],'name',\{properties}) | creates a virtual graph object for later processing
fromData.description: apoc.graph.fromData(nodes :: LIST? OF NODE?, relationships :: LIST? OF RELATIONSHIP?, name :: STRING?, properties :: MAP?) :: (graph :: MAP?)

from.name: apoc.graph.from(data,'name',\{properties}) | creates a virtual graph object for later processing it tries its best to extract the graph information from the data you pass in
from.description: apoc.graph.from(data :: ANY?, name :: STRING?, properties :: MAP?) :: (graph :: MAP?)

fromPath.name: apoc.graph.fromPaths(path,'name',\{properties}) - creates a virtual graph object for later processing
fromPath.description: apoc.graph.fromPath(path :: PATH?, name :: STRING?, properties :: MAP?) :: (graph :: MAP?)

validateDocument.name: apoc.graph.validateDocument(\{json}, \{config}) yield row - validates the json, return the result of the validation

fromPaths.name: apoc.graph.fromPaths([paths],'name',\{properties}) - creates a virtual graph object for later processing
fromPaths.description: apoc.graph.fromPaths(paths :: LIST? OF PATH?, name :: STRING?, properties :: MAP?) :: (graph :: MAP?)

fromCypher.name: apoc.graph.fromCypher('kernelTransaction',\{params},'name',\{properties}) - creates a virtual graph object for later processing
fromCypher.description: apoc.graph.fromCypher(kernelTransaction :: STRING?, params :: MAP?, name :: STRING?, properties :: MAP?) :: (graph :: MAP?)

fromDB.name: apoc.graph.fromDB('name',\{properties}) - creates a virtual graph object for later processing

fromDocument.name: apoc.graph.fromDocument(\{json}, \{config}) yield graph - transform JSON documents into graph structures

jdbc.name: apoc.model.jdbc('key or url', {schema:'<schema>', write: <true/false>, filters: { tables:[], views: [], columns: []}) YIELD nodes, relationships - load schema from relational database
jdbc.description: apoc.model.jdbc(jdbc :: STRING?, config = {} :: MAP?) :: (nodes :: LIST? OF NODE?, relationships :: LIST? OF RELATIONSHIP?)

validatePredicate.name: apoc.util.validatePredicate(predicate, message, params) | if the predicate yields to true raise an exception else returns true, for use inside WHERE subclauses
validatePredicate.description: apoc.util.validatePredicate(predicate :: BOOLEAN?, message :: STRING?, params :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: (BOOLEAN?)

sha1.name: apoc.util.sha1([values]) | computes the sha1 of the concatenation of all string values of the list

sha256.name: apoc.util.sha256([values]) | computes the sha256 of the concatenation of all string values of the list

sha512.name: apoc.util.sha512([values]) | computes the sha512 of the concatenation of all string values of the list

compress.name: apoc.util.compress(string, \{config}) | return a compressed byte[] in various format from a string

sleep.name: apoc.util.sleep(<duration>) | sleeps for <duration> millis, transaction termination is honored

sha384.name: apoc.util.sha384([values]) | computes the sha384 of the concatenation of all string values of the list

validate.name: apoc.util.validate(predicate, message, params) | if the predicate yields to true raise an exception
validate.description: apoc.util.validate(predicate :: BOOLEAN?, message :: STRING?, params :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: VOID

decompress.name: apoc.util.decompress(compressed, \{config}) | return a string from a compressed byte[] in various format

md5.name: apoc.util.md5([values]) | computes the md5 of the concatenation of all string values of the list

url.name: apoc.data.url('url') as {protocol,host,port,path,query,file,anchor,user} | turn URL into map structure

domain.name: apoc.data.domain('url_or_email_address') YIELD domain - extract the domain name from a url or an email address. If nothing was found, yield null.

email.name: apoc.data.email('email_address') as {personal,user,domain} - extract the personal name, user and domain as a map

nodes.name: apoc.lock.nodes([nodes]) acquires a write lock on the given nodes

read.name: apoc.lock.read.nodes([nodes]) acquires a read lock on the given nodes

rels.name: apoc.lock.rels([relationships]) acquires a write lock on the given relationship

all.name: apoc.lock.all([nodes],[relationships]) acquires a write lock on the given nodes and relationships
all.description: apoc.lock.all(nodes :: LIST? OF NODE?, rels :: LIST? OF RELATIONSHIP?) :: VOID

fingerprinting.name: calculate a checksum (md5) over a node or a relationship. This deals gracefully with array properties. Two identical entities do share the same hash.

fingerprintGraph.name: calculate a checksum (md5) over a the full graph. Be aware that this function does use in-memomry datastructures depending on the size of your graph.

fingerprint.name: calculate a checksum (md5) over a node or a relationship. This deals gracefully with array properties. Two identical entities do share the same hash.
fingerprint.description: apoc.hashing.fingerprint(some object :: ANY?, propertyExcludes = [] :: LIST? OF STRING?) :: (STRING?)

get.name: apoc.static.get(name) - returns statically stored value from config (apoc.static.<key>) or server lifetime storage

list.name: apoc.static.list(prefix) - returns statically stored values from config (apoc.static.<prefix>.*) or server lifetime storage

getAll.name: apoc.static.getAll(prefix) - returns statically stored values from config (apoc.static.<prefix>.*) or server lifetime storage

set.name: apoc.static.set(name, value) - stores value under key for server lifetime storage, returns previously stored or configured value

debug.name: apoc.log.debug(message, params) - logs debug message
debug.description: apoc.log.debug(message :: STRING?, params = [] :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: VOID

stream.name: apoc.log.stream('neo4j.log', { last: n }) - retrieve log file contents, optionally return only the last n lines
stream.description: apoc.log.stream(path :: STRING?, config = {} :: MAP?) :: (lineNo :: INTEGER?, line :: STRING?, path :: STRING?)

info.name: apoc.log.info(message, params) - logs info message
info.description: apoc.log.info(message :: STRING?, params = [] :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: VOID

error.name: apoc.log.error(message, params) - logs error message
error.description: apoc.log.error(message :: STRING?, params = [] :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: VOID

warn.name: apoc.log.warn(message, params) - logs warn message
warn.description: apoc.log.warn(message :: STRING?, params = [] :: LIST? OF ANY?) :: VOID

op.name: apoc.bitwise.op(60,'|',13) bitwise operations a & b, a | b, a ^ b, ~a, a >> b, a >>> b, a << b. returns the result of the bitwise operation
op.description: apoc.bitwise.op(a :: INTEGER?, operator :: STRING?, b :: INTEGER?) :: (INTEGER?)
